Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Synthetic Applications of Trichloromethyl Carbinols
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will continue the development of methods involving gem-dichloroepoxide intermediates for the safe and economical preparation of substituted carbonyl compounds and biomolecule analogs. Established routes to such materials generally require inefficient reaction steps, expensive reagents, or dangerous reaction conditions. Studies to establish safer and shorter methods for homologating carboxylic acids and preparing beta-amino acids, deoxy-C-glycosides and amino-C-glycosides from readily available trichloromethyl carbinols will be explored. The resultant products will be evaluated in terms of yield, preparation cost, and the stereo- and regioselectivities of devised reaction steps. Structure-reactivity analyses and product analyses under carefully adjusted reaction conditions will also demonstrate how specific parameters affect the formation and reactivity of the transient gem-dichloroepoxide intermediates involved in each method.

With this award, the Organic and Macromolecular Chemistry Program is supporting the research of Professor Timothy Snowden of the Department of Chemistry at The University of Alabama. Professor Snowden's research efforts revolve around providing safer and more efficient methods to prepare synthetically versatile substituted carbonyl compounds, and therapeutically valuable unnatural amino acids and heterocycles. These methods will offer marked improvements in environmental influence, operational safety, and materials costs over currently employed approaches. Successful development of the methodology will have an impact on synthesis in academic research programs and in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and materials science fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of new chemical reactions provides cheaper, safer, and more effective tools for the preparation of medicines, polymers, pigments, and thousands of other materials used daily. The funded research that we conducted involved the preparation and use of stable and easily handled trichloromethyl carbinols for applications in new chemical reactions. One of those research efforts was focused on limiting the number of chemical steps required to prepare common classes of organic compounds--specifically, homologated alcohols and carboxylic acid derivatives. A homologated organic compound is a molecule composed of carbon (and typically hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and other atoms) whose length has been extended by one carbon unit--much like adding a link to a chain that is just a bit too short to be useful. Homologation reactions are frequently employed to convert readily available chemicals into extended organic compounds of greater value or utility. We developed two new one-carbon homologation reactions that require fewer steps and which work with a broader range of organic molecules than any other homologation reactions yet reported.

In another study, we used a trichloromethyl carbinol to prepare a biologically active molecule designated HPA-12. It blocks a protein called CERT which is involved in the interconversion of signaling molecules within cells. Inappropriate levels of those molecules can promote diseases including specific autoimmune disorders. HPA-12 is used as a probe in biological studies to determine the role of CERT in cellular activities and in the initiation and progression of select diseases. Our synthesis of HPA-12 highlighted a new synthetic application of trichloromethyl carbinols and featured an efficient preparation of HPA-12. In addition, it provided a recipe for conveniently preparing the probe for use in future biological studies.

A third focus was to develop a way to synthesize either a desired single stereoisomer or a complete library of deoxy-C-glycosides starting from trichloromethyl carbinols. Deoxy-C-glycosides mimic some of the sugars found in nature but offer increased thermal, chemical, and biochemical stability relative to their natural counterparts. They have been extensively investigated in drug discovery efforts, but their preparations are commonly lengthy, complex, and inefficient. We are completing the optimization of new synthetic methods for preparing any desired stereoisomer of a wide variety of chiral deoxy-C-glycosides in only five or six operational steps. A slight modification can be used to create chemical libraries of isomers for potential drug discovery efforts in even fewer reaction steps.

Our research investigations provided hands-on training in chemical synthesis and structure determination for 11 undergraduate researchers, 1 postdoctoral researcher, and 6 graduate students (including one who recently earned his PhD degree, one who earned an MS degree and is now a high school science teacher, and two who are scheduled to defend their dissertation research for their PhD degrees in Fall 2015). All participants played important roles in the research investigations; received extensive training in laboratory safety, experimental research techniques, and advanced methods for determining molecular structure; and gained practical knowledge about chemical structure and reactivity that could not have been learned in the classroom. The students worked as teams to investigate the new chemical reactions and to record and report their findings. Such group efforts, data management, technical communication (all professional development activities), and practical research skills made possible through this funding will benefit the participants in their future vocations as research scientists, teachers, medical doctors, or other professionals.
